title: Asia: Global Growth Continues Its Momentum, Say Citi Economists
summary: Citi economists expect strong global growth this year and next, with global GDP rising 3.5 to 4 percent, well above the long-run average of just below 3 percent year-on-year.
tag-1: Asia: Global Growth Continues Its Momentum, Say Citi Economists
tag-2: Citi economists expect strong global growth this year and next, with global GDP rising 3.5 to 4 percent, well above the long-run average of just below 3 percent year-on-year.
tag-3: The views were presented at a media briefing hosted by Citi economists, led by Willem Buiter; global chief economist, David Lubin, head of emerging markets economics; Johanna Chua, Asia Pacific chief economist and Shen Minggao, China equity strategist, who are on a week's visit to China.
tag-4: "We expect U.S. GDP growth to rebound to about 3 percent quarter-on-quarter in the second quarter, buoyed by solid job growth, strong business investment and less drag from energy costs. The slowdown in China is likely to prove mild, and, in terms of quarter-on-quarter GDP growth, the second quarter is likely to prove the weakest quarter," said Buiter in his opening remarks. He added that growth is expected to remain uneven, and many economies will not be growing particularly strongly this year and in 2012.
tag-5: He further added that the European Central Bank (ECB) will most likely signal another 25 bp rate hike in July at its upcoming meeting later this month to about 2.5 percent by end 2012, while U.S. Fed is likely to maintain its rates for the remaining of the year – provided the economy improves as expected and financial conditions remain supportive.
tag-6: Against this background, Citi strategists expect the U.S. dollar to strengthen near term, but weaken medium term.
tag-7: "We believe the recent widening in credit spreads probably has further to run, but look for about 10 percent further upside in global equities by year-end. We advocate caution and expect industrial country bond yields to rise in H2 this year," added Buiter.
tag-8: Johanna Chua cautioned a global cyclical slowdown in Asia after the region posted stronger-than-expected economic activity in the first quarter, with external demand softening from the global industrial cycle and the impact of Japan supply disruptions.
tag-9: "While growth in the emerging market is holding up better, China's growth is slowing, although it is largely in line with our forecast of 9.2 percent for 2011 and 9 percent for 2012," Chua said.
tag-10: She explained, "This is coming against the backdrop of a strong first quarter for Asia, where strong exports played a role in the significant positive growth surprises we saw in China, Singapore, H.K., Taiwan and Thailand."
tag-11: While China's economy is showing initial signs of a slowdown on tighter policies, power shortage and inventory destocking, Citi economists are confident that a major downturn can be avoided via policy, possibly less monetary tightening as inflation eases, and electricity tariff adjustments to boost power production.
